abstracts.cdata!:
The Senegal Integrated Health Sector
            Development Project had an unsatisfactory outcome, likely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impact, and
            overall unsatisfactory Bank and Borrower performances.
            Lessons gleaned from this project concerned: 1) in project
            preparation, applying realism (adopting limited but
            reachable objectives) and appropriate lending instrument
            (choosing according to the Borrower's circumstances);
            2) supporting institutional capacity development by starting
            with an independent audit leading to a shared diagnosis and
            to agreed priorities; 3)  choosing the right health sector
            indicators to closely monitor results; and 4) auditing
            financial management and procurement in such a way as to
            make more room for an economic approach. The current
            auditing process - in which the government prepares the
            terms of reference and chooses the auditor - is not fully
            satisfactory. The audit is not as in-depth as with a more
            independently chosen auditor. In the terms of reference, the
            audit should not only certify the accounts but also conduct
            an economic analysis of prices paid and the relevance of
            using goods and services procured under the project. The
            periodic Statement of Expenditures reviews are not
            sufficient to track all misuses of funds. This approach may
            add costs to implementing a project, but is important in
            order to ensure better governance, reduce corruption, and
            get the best value for money spent.
